page.title: 06HARRIS TWEED
page.content: After the Blackface sheep are shorn in the summer the fleeces are washed and dried ready for dyeing.Many of the dyes used are natural dyes found locally.Some examples are :ragweed- "buaghallan"-orange heather "froach" green.Cortal scraped from the rocks gives shades of brown.Next the wool is combed ready for carding.This produces thick strands-"rollagan"-which are spun into thread on a spinning wheel- "cuibheall-sniamh".The spun thread wound into balls is the warping thread ready for the loom.Wool for the weft is wound onto bobbins- "iteachain" -ready for the shuttle. Today all the wool is mill spun and only the weaving must still be done by the individual weaver at home if the tweed is to qualify for the Orb Stamp. The Orb Stamp was introduced in 1934 and is the sign of genuine Harris Tweed.
